newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Belgians fear Dow might spoil party again.
newsitem.headline: Belgians fear Dow might spoil party again.

text.p: Belgian shares, once again the victim of wild mood swings on Wednesday, comfortably gained 0.89 percent but at the same time wondered how long the euphoria would last.

Relief after Tuesday's FOMC decision, after the close on Tuesday, to leave rates unchanged and the rise on Wall Street and bonds, pushed the Bel-20 index up 19.83 points to 2,247.83 -- just 24 points below its all-time high.
But the thought of new record levels prompted acute vertigo for the Belgian market which feared again the U.S. engine would soon start sputtering again.
"Everything hinges on New York," said Gert De Mesure at Delen Bank.
U.S. stocks, still pleased that the Fed decided to leave rates unchanged, built further on Tuesday's gains in early business on Wednesday.
But traders said that the next batch of U.S. data could already make the bubble burst.
The Bel-20 will also have to overcome a new bout of dividend coupon payouts on May 27 en route to any new record levels.
Insurer Fortis AG was the day's leading gainer with a 3.3 percent rise to 6,540 francs.
De Mesure said AG might be moving in sympathy with Dutch financial group ING, which was lifted nearly six percent by new details of its profitability.
Electronics firm Barco rose 1.6 percent to 6,370 but De Mesure noted it had slipped in recent days from 6,540.
One trader noted that Barco was also being supported by buying related to the imminent bourse listing of Belgium's Flemish regional investment company GIMV.
GIMV's main interests include 33.5 percent of Barco.
The Flemish government, which owns 85 percent of GIMV, will float 14.8 percent of its holding.
Cement maker CBR was one of two Bel-20 losers, dropping 15 francs to 3,480. De Mesure said it appeared to be under pressure from one seller.
Non-ferrous metals firm Union Miniere was down slightly most of the day on profit-taking, but recovered near the close to end unchanged at 2,880.
